explanation: The weekend is almost here! Friday marks the end of the work week and the start of well-deserved rest.
ISO 8601 divides each year into 52 or 53 weeks. Week 1 is the week containing the first Thursday of the year. Swedes organize their lives by week numbers.
The month is almost over. Time to wrap up monthly goals and prepare for the next chapter.
Track your monthly progress. This percentage shows how far through the current month we are.
Another day, another step through the year. This shows how far along we are in the current calendar year.
Sunday is traditionally a day of rest in many cultures. Named after the Sun, it's perfect for recharging before the new week.
Monday is named after the Moon. In Swedish it's Mandag. A fresh start to tackle the week ahead!
TGIF! Friday is named after Norse goddess Frigg. In Sweden, Fridays mean fredagsmys - cozy evenings with family, snacks, and TV.
Saturday is the day for errands, adventures, or simply doing nothing. Named after Saturn, the Roman god of agriculture.
January resets our week counter! Week 1 begins, and Swedes everywhere start planning their year by week numbers.
The shortest month brings Valentines Day and semla season in Sweden - cream-filled cardamom buns enjoyed before Lent.
March marks the spring equinox. Days grow longer, and nature begins to wake from winter slumber.
April often brings Easter celebrations and Swedish children dressed as Easter witches going door-to-door.
May 1st is a public holiday in Sweden. Spring is in full bloom and outdoor life resumes after the long winter.
June brings the longest days and Swedens beloved Midsommar celebration - dancing around the maypole, eating pickled herring, and celebrating the midnight sun.
July is peak vacation season. Most Swedes take their industrisemester - the traditional summer holiday when many businesses close.
August brings Swedish crayfish parties (kraftskiva) with paper hats, singing, and plenty of schnapps.
September marks the end of summer vacation. Schools reopen and work routines resume after the long Swedish summer break.
October 4th is Kanelbullens dag - National Cinnamon Bun Day in Sweden. Millions of kanelbullar are consumed!
November brings early darkness and the Swedish tradition of mys - coziness with candles, blankets, and warm drinks.
December brings Advent calendars, Lucia celebrations, glogg (mulled wine), and of course - Donald Duck on TV at 3 PM on Christmas Eve.

textTemplate: Q1: first quarter of the year
explanation: The first quarter spans January through March. A time for fresh starts and setting goals for the year ahead.
The second quarter spans April through June. Spring energy and longer days fuel productivity.
The third quarter spans July through September. Summer vacations and back-to-routine transitions.
The fourth quarter spans October through December. Time to finish strong and prepare for the holidays.
Each month has a different number of days. February is shortest (28-29), while January, March, May, July, August, October, and December have 31.
The day of year counts from January 1st. This helps track progress through the calendar year.
Counting down the weeks helps plan the remaining year and set achievable goals.
